metadata.case_name: Appellant v. State (through Messrs. Mohan Lal Hargovind Das)

facts.text: On April 26, 1954, the appellant was arrested by the Sisamau Police for offences under ss. 420, 482, 483, 485 and 486 of the Indian Penal Code on the allegation that he was in possession of 25 packets of Chand Chhap Biri, which were alleged to bear counterfeit trade marks.

On May 26, 1954, one Harish Chandra Jain acting on behalf of Messrs. Mohan Lal Hargovind Das filed a complaint charging that the appellant was in possession of counterfeit bidis, wrappers and labels and praying that a case under the sections above mentioned be registered and investigated.
The Magistrate passed the order: 'O. Sisamau. Please investigate and register a case.'
After investigation, the police submitted their chargesheet on September 30, 1954.
Summons was ordered to the appellant on July 22, 1955.

On September 17, 1955, the appellant filed an application before the Magistrate raising preliminary objection that proceedings were barred by s. 15 of the Indian Merchandise Marks Act, 1889, as offence discovered on April 26, 1954, and process issued beyond one year.
Revision to Additional Sessions Judge, Kanpur (Criminal Revision No. 13 of 1956) rejected.

Further Revision to Allahabad High Court (Criminal Revision No. 1594 of 1956), heard by James and Takru, JJ., judgment dated May 14, 1958, holding prosecution commenced on May 26, 1954, within time; granted leave to appeal to Supreme Court under Art. 134(1)(c).

legal_issues.text: When does a prosecution commence for purposes of s. 15 of the Indian Merchandise Marks Act, 1889, whether on the date when the complaint is preferred, or when the process is issued thereon?

petitioner_arguments.text: Proceedings barred by s. 15 as discovery on April 26, 1954, process issued July 22, 1955 beyond one year; prosecution commences only when process issued.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 15 Indian Merchandise Marks Act; Sheik Meeran Sahib v. Ratnavelu Mudali; De Rozario v. Gulab Chand Anundjee; Golap Jan v. Bholanath Khettry; R.R. Chari v. State of Uttar Pradesh

respondent_arguments.text: Prosecution commenced when complaint presented on May 26, 1954, within one year of discovery on April 26, 1954.

court_reasoning.text: Under the law, a prosecution at the instance of a private prosecutor commences when the complaint is preferred; settled law unless statute provides otherwise; Halsbury's Laws confirms this.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Date of presentation of private complaint marks commencement of prosecution.

court_reasoning.text: Nature of prosecution under Merchandise Marks Act is private complaint to protect trade mark rights speedily; s.15 limitation ensures diligence of complainant, not court delays.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Object defeated if process issue date controls; cites Ruppell v. Ponnuswami Tevan.

court_reasoning.text: Cases on malicious prosecution (Sheik Meeran etc.) distinguished as they concern whether prosecution occurred, not when it commenced; R.R. Chari distinguished as police investigation, not private complaint under CrPC s.190(1)(a).

holdings.text: Prosecution under s.15 commences when private complaint is preferred, not when process issued; proceedings not barred.

precedents_cited.relevance: Prosecution must commence within one year of discovery by complainant; limitation on complainantâ€™s diligence.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sheik Meeran Sahib v. Ratnavelu Mudali
precedents_cited.relevance: Malicious prosecution cases where no process issued means no prosecution; not applicable to commencement date.

precedents_cited.case_name: De Rozario v. Gulab Chand Anundjee

precedents_cited.relevance: Same as above; may need reconsideration per Privy Council.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mohamed Amin v. Jogendra Kumar Bannerjee
precedents_cited.relevance: Test for malicious prosecution: stage where damage results, not mere filing.

precedents_cited.case_name: R.R. Chari v. The State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: No prosecution until cognizance in police cases; private complaints differ under CrPC s.190(1)(a).
Distinction between initiation and cognizance under CrPC ss.200,202 not relevant here.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences alleged: cheating and trade mark counterfeiting.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Merchandise Marks Act, 1889
statutes_cited.relevance: s.15 limitation for prosecution; ss.13,14 on evidence and costs in trade mark prosecutions.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Cognizance on private complaint; distinction from police cases.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Leave to appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: The appeal is dismissed. The Supreme Court agrees with the High Court that the prosecution commenced on the date the complaint was filed on May 26, 1954, within one year of discovery on April 26, 1954, and is not barred by s.15 of the Indian Merchandise Marks Act.

key_quotes.text: "unless there is something to the contrary in the statute, when a private complaint is presented it is the date of presentation thereof that marks the commencement of the prosecution."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on commencement of private prosecution.

key_quotes.text: The period of limitation... is intended to operate against the complainant and to ensure diligence on his part... and not against the Court.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains purpose of s.15; protects against court delays.

key_quotes.text: "No such prosecution... shall be commenced after the expiration of three years next after the commission of the offence, or one year after the first discovery thereof by the prosecutor, whichever expiration first happens."
key_quotes.speaker: court
